{{Infobox scientist | name = Philippe Cadène | image = Philippe Cadène.jpg | birth_date = 1955 | birth_place = South of France | death_date = | nationality = French | institution = Université Paris Diderot | alma_mater = | thesis_title = Conflits sociaux et rivalités paysannes pour l'espace péri-urbain : une analyse des processus du changement autour des dix grandes agglomérations françaises | thesis_year = 1985 | fields = geography, anthropology | known_for = | notable_ideas = | influences = | influenced = }} '''Philippe Cadène''' is a professor of [[geography]] at [[Paris Diderot University]], affiliated to the Centre d'études en sciences sociales sur les mondes africains, américains et asiatiques ([[CESSMA]])<ref>{{cite web|title=CADENE Philippe - CESSMA - Centre d’études en sciences sociales sur les mondes africains, américains et asiatiques|url=http://www.cessma.univ-paris-diderot.fr/spip.php?article70|author=CADENE Philippe|agency=Cessma.univ-paris-diderot.fr|language=fr|access-date=2017-04-14}}</ref>. Although he is particularly known for his works on economic development in India <ref>{{cite web|title=Philippe Cadene : biographie, actualités et émissions France Culture|url=https://www.franceculture.fr/personne-philippe-cadene-0|agency=Franceculture.fr|language=fr|access-date=2017-04-14}}</ref>, his research on globalization also led him to study South-East Asia and the Gulf countries.
== Biography == Philippe Cadène was born in 1955 in the South of France. He studied at the University of Toulouse II-Le Mirail where he defended his Ph.D. thesis, supervised by Professor Bernard Kayser, in 1985. His initial works examined the socio-economic changes related to the urbanisation of rural areas, particularly in the periurban areas.<ref>Cadène, P. (1985). Conflits sociaux et rivalités paysannes pour l'espace périurbain. Une analyse du changement social à la périphérie de dix grandes agglomérations françaises. Thèse d’Etat Université de Toulouse 2 Le Mirail</ref><ref>Cadène, P. (1990). L'usage des espaces péri-urbains: Une géographie régionale des conflits. Etudes rurales, 235-267.</ref> In the early 1980's, Philippe Cadène started doing research on small and medium sized towns in India, where he highlighted the emergence of industrial districts as hubs of multiple networks built around new and ancient local communities.<ref>Cadène, P. (1989). Le développement de la petite industrie: le cas du marbre au Sud-Rajasthan. Revue Tiers Monde, 673-693.</ref><ref>Cadène, P. (1993). Réseaux économiques et territoires de l’identité: migrations de travail et migrations de mariage des membres d’une communauté marchande dans une petite ville indienne. Cah. Sci. Hum, 29(2-3), 443-463.</ref><ref>Cadene, P. (1998). Network specialists, industrial clusters and the integration of space in India. Decentralized Production in India: Industrial Districts, Flexible Specialization, and Employment, 139-165.</ref> He has since extended his work to the cities of the Gulf countries, where he analysed the socioeconomic changes in the region.<ref>Cadène, P. (2012). Croissance urbaine, migrations et diversification sociale dans le golfe Arabo-persique. Espace populations sociétés. Space populations societies, (2012/2), 15-32.</ref><ref>Cadène, P. (2013). Koweït City: planification urbaine et stratégie régionale. Arabian Humanities. Revue internationale d’archéologie et de sciences sociales sur la péninsule Arabique/International Journal of Archaeology and Social Sciences in the Arabian Peninsula, (2).</ref>
After concluding a series of research projects in India at the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), at the Institute of Development Studies (IDS) at the University of Sussex in the United Kingdom, and at the Sudasien Institut at the University of Heidelberg in Germany, he was appointed research fellow at the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) within the Centre d'Etudes de l'Inde et de l'Asie du Sud (CEIAS) of the Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales (EHESS).
His research subsequently focused on the economic and regional dynamics in India in which cities play an important role. In 1995, he got a position of professor in urban geography at the University of Paul Valéry in Montpellier. He then began his research within the Maison de la Géographie de Montpellier created by Roger Brunet and participated in the creation of the research centre ESPACE (Unité Mixte de Recherche).
In 2000, he was appointed Professor in development studies at Paris Diderot University. While continuing his research on India, his teaching and research extended beyond South Asia, in diverse Asian countries and more particularly in the Gulf countries. His publications then focused on the issues of globalisation and regional development <ref>Cadène, P. (2012). Urban growth, migrations, and social diversificatio in the Arabo-persian gulf. Espace populations sociétés. Space populations societies, (2012/2), 15-32.</ref>{{,}}<ref>Cadène, P. (2013). Koweït City: planification urbaine et stratégie régionale. Arabian Humanities. Revue internationale d’archéologie et de sciences sociales sur la péninsule Arabique/International Journal of Archaeology and Social Sciences in the Arabian Peninsula, (2).</ref>{{,}}<ref>Cadène, P., & Bautes, N. (2006). La mondialisation: l'intégration des pays en développement. Sedes.</ref>, which he notably taught at [[Sciences Po Paris]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Geography of Global Asia | Sciences Po, Portail de la Scolarité|url=http://formation.sciences-po.fr/enseignement/2015/BIPO/1100A|agency=Formation.sciences-po.fr|language=fr|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170406022058/http://formation.sciences-po.fr/enseignement/2015/BIPO/1100A|archive-date=6 April 2017|access-date=2017-04-14}}</ref>. He also published various textbooks and atlases for students and the general public <ref>Cadène, P. (2004). Le commentaire de cartes et de documents géographiques. Belin.</ref>{{,}}<ref>Cadène, P., Roda, J. M., Guizol, P., Santoso, L., & Fauzan, A. U. (2007). Atlas of wooden furniture industry in Jepara, Indonesia. Cifor.</ref>{{,}}<ref>Cadène, P. (2008). Atlas de l'Inde: une fulgurante ascension. Ed. Autrement.</ref>{{,}}<ref>Cadène, P., & Dumortier, B. (2013). Atlas of the Gulf States. Brill.</ref>{{,}}<ref>Cadène, P. (ed., 2015), L’Inde: une géographie, Paris: CNED : A. Colin.</ref>.
During his career, Philippe Cadène has also been professor and invited researcher in several institutes of research and teaching in Asia : the Institut Français de Pondicherry, the University of Kyoto, the University of Séoul, the University of Utara Malaysia, the University of Kebamgsaan Malaysia, and the Université of Sorbonne Abu Dhabi. He also often teaches at the Tata Institute of Social Sciences in Mumbai.
== Scientific approach == Trained to structuralist approaches in geography and anthropology, Philippe Cadène uses systemic and interdisciplinary methodologies and emphasises on qualitative data collection and long-term fieldworks. He tries to consider the various scales in which social processes are embedded, and he mixes quantitative and qualitative data to understand the dynamics of territorial systems. He generally approaches globalisation as a multi-scale process of territorial production. He also pays particular attention to the cities and the political relations between them within increasingly large regional boundaries.
== Major publications == * Philippe Cadène, La construction d'une vaste région économique au nord-ouest de l'Inde : le corridor de développement Delhi-Mumbai (the building of a large economic region in North-West India; the Delhi-Mumbai development corridor), ''Bulletin de l'Association des Géographes Français (BAGF)'', pp.40-61, 2017 * Philippe Cadène, La géographie comme science sociale à l'ère de la mondialisation (Geography as social sciences at the time of globalisation), in ''Gukto (Planning and Policy)'', n° 351, Korea Research Institute for Human Settlements, 2011 * Philippe Cadène, Société de la connaissance et politiques de développement aux Emirats Arabes Unis (Knowledge society and development policy in the UAE), ''Maghreb-Machrek'', n° 195, 2008 * Philippe Cadène, L’Asie du Sud dans la mondialisation (South Asia towards globalization), in P. Cadène (Ed.), ''Mondialisation. L’intégration des pays en développement'', Paris, SEDES, Coll. DIEM, 2007 * Philippe Cadène, La dynamique spatiale des grandes entreprises en Inde (The spatial dynamics of big enterprises in India), in Kermel D. et all. (Eds.), ''Dynamiques spatiales de l'industrialisation. Chine, Inde, Thaïlande,'' Paris, UNESCO, 2003 * Philippe Cadène, Industrial districts and integration of Indian space, in P. Cadène et M. Holmstrom (Eds), ''Decentralized production in India. Industrial districts, flexible specialization and employment'', New-Delhi, Sage Publications, 1998 * Philippe Cadène, Le rôle des castes marchandes dans l'économie indienne aujourd'hui. Le cas des Jains dans une petite ville du Rajasthan (The importance of merchant castes in the contemporary Indian economy: the case of the Jains in a small town of Rajasthan), in ''Les Cahiers de la Recherche Architecturale'', 1995, n°35-36 * Philippe Cadène, L'usage des espaces péri-urbains: Une géographie régionale des conflits 5The use of periurban space in France. A regional geography of social conflicts), in ''Etudes rurales'', n°118-119, 1990, pp. 235-267. * Philippe Cadène, Le développement de la petite industrie : le cas du marbre au Sud-Rajasthan (Development of small scale industry: the case of marble in South-Rajasthan), in ''Revue Tiers-Monde,'' n°119, 1989, pp. 673-694.
== References == {{reflist}}

page.title: Presidents of the Regional Government of Madeira

revision.text:
{{Infobox official post |post = President |body = the Regional Government of Madeira |native_name = ''{{small|Presidente do Governo Regional
da Madeira}}'' |flag = Flag of Madeira.svg |flagsize = |flagborder = |flagcaption = [[Flag of Madeira]] |insignia = Coat of arms of Madeira.png |insigniasize = |insigniacaption = [[Coat of arms of Madeira]] |department = |image = Saint Helier - Funchal 2012 13.jpg |imagesize = 165px |alt = |incumbent = [[Miguel Albuquerque]] |incumbentsince = 20 April 2015 |style = His/Her [[Excellency]] |residence = Quinta Vigia, [[Funchal]] |nominator = |appointer = Representative of the Republic |termlength = 4 years ([[Legislative Assembly of Madeira]] may be dissolved sooner);
no term limits. |inaugural = [[Jaime Ornelas Camacho]] |formation = 1 October 1976 |last = |abolished = |succession = |deputy = |salary = |website = {{URL|http://www.madeira.gov.pt/|www.madeira.gov.pt}} }} '''Presidents of the Regional Government of Madeira''' are the [[Head of government|heads of government]] for the autonomous local authority of [[Madeira]], since the [[Carnation Revolution]] that installed the [[Democracy|democratic]] [[Third Portuguese Republic]]. The list below includes the leaders of the transitional regimes and those presidents designated after the institutionalization of the [[:pt:Estatuto Político Administrativo da Região Autónoma da Madeira|autonomy statute]] that provided archipelago with its laws and democratic rights. Following the first elections, held on 27 June 1976, the leader of the first party was installed as first President of the Regional Government of Madeira ([[Jaime Ornelas Camacho]]), responsible for forming his executive and cabinet to administer the functioning of the public service in Madeira. ==Presidents== The numbering reflects the uninterrupted terms in office served by each president. For example, [[Alberto João Jardim]] served for ten consecutive terms and is counted as the second president (not the seventh, eighth, ninth or tenth president): the Roman numerals refer to the legislature that their terms encompassed. [[Carlos Manuel de Azeredo]] and [[Joaquim Miguel Duarte Silva]] served as presidents of the Regional Junta, the provisional government that functioned during the transition towards democracy. The current President of the Regional Government of Madeira is [[Miguel Albuquerque]], whose party won the [[Madeira regional election, 2015]] on 29 March 2015. The colors indicate the political affiliation of each President. :{{legend2|#FFFDD0|No party|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} :{{legend2|#FFCC99|[[Social Democratic Party (Portugal)|Social Democratic]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- style="background:#cccccc" ! style="width: 50px;" |Term ! style="width: 15px;" |# !! style="width: 200px;" |President
(Birth–Death) !!Portrait!! style="width: 150px;" |Took office !! style="width: 150px;"| Left office !! style="width: 150px;" | Party |- style="background:#DCDCDC" ! colspan=7 | Regional Junta of Madeira (1976) |- style="background:#cccccc" || - || style="background:blue; color:white;" |
'''-''' || '''[[Carlos Manuel de Azeredo]]'''
b. 1930 || [[File:No image.png|80px]] || 20 February 1976 || 20 August 1976 || [[Armed Forces Movement]] |- style="background:#cccccc" || - || style="background:blue; color:white;" |
'''-''' || '''[[Joaquim Miguel Duarte Silva]]'''
b. 1924 - d. 2007 || [[File:No image.png|80px]] || 20 August 1976 || 1 October 1976 || [[Armed Forces Movement]] |- style="background:#DCDCDC" ! colspan=7 | Regional Government of Madeira (1976–Present) |- style="background:#FFCC99" || I || style="background:{{Social Democratic Party (Portugal)/meta/color}}; color:white;" |
'''1''' || '''[[Jaime Ornelas Camacho]]'''

{{Use Australian English|date=September 2013}}
==Fatal Accidents==
===Bridgewater, 1886=== On 22 July 1886 an express train from [[Launceston, Tasmania|Launceston]] whilst crossing the viaduct at [[Bridgewater, Tasmania|Bridgewater]], the swing bridge opened and the engine fell into the river. The fireman and another person were supposed to have drowned.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bridgewater Railway Accident|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=WT18860724.2.14&l=mi&e=-------10--1----0-all|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref>
===[[Zeehan, Tasmania|Zeehan]], 1887=== 2 killed. {{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}
===Campania, 1916=== On 15 February 1916, seven<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1027681|title=CAMPANIA RAILWAY DISASTER|date=1916-03-08|work=Mercury (Hobart, Tas. : 1860 - 1954)|access-date=2018-03-24|pages=7}}</ref> passengers were killed and twenty nine seriously injured when the express from Launceston to [[Hobart]], with 200 passengers on board, was derailed {{convert|2|mi|km|abbr=in|order=flip}} north of [[Campania]], and {{convert|29|mi|km|abbr=in|order=flip}} from Hobart. The engine jumped the rails, and dragged after it the three front carriages. The carriage nearest the engine was smashed to pieces, while several others received injuries.
The accident occurred just before 4<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1044270|title=STATEMENTS OF LOCAL PEOPLE.|date=1916-02-16|work=Mercury (Hobart, Tas. : 1860 - 1954)|access-date=2018-03-24|pages=5}}</ref> o'clock. The train was rounding a curve, but a fairly easy one, as compared to some of the curves higher up the line. According to the statements of passengers, the speed was not very great, and no one seems to have any idea how the accident occurred.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hobart Express wrecked|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1044274?searchTerm=campania+railway+disaster|publisher=The Mercury|accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref>
===Conara, 1992=== On 1 December 1992, one person was killed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Conara train/bus crash|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/c85916e930b93d50ca256d050020cb1f/caa0d85ded7e9375ca256d3300057b73?OpenDocument|publisher=EMA Database|accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref>
===Launceston, 2006=== One person killed. The freight company [[Pacific National]] has admitted that it failed to provide a safe work system when a man died at its Launceston (East Tamar maintenance depot) rail-yards. The man was killed at Pacific National's when a wagon he was inspecting was shunted from the other end and pinned him.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pacific Nation 'Very Remorseful'|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/12/12/2116806.htm?site=northtas|publisher=ABC Northern Tasmania|accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref>
===Spreyton, 2010=== On 26 September 2010 a boy was killed when his [[all-terrain vehicle]] collided with a train on a private road in Tasmania's north. The teenager failed to stop at a stop sign on a private driveway and rode into the path of a train carrying cement at [[Spreyton]], just south of [[Devonport, Tasmania|Devonport]]. He was thrown under the train and died instantly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Train, ATV Collision|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/8058879/young-man-killed-at-rail-crossing|publisher=9 News|accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref>
Restoring citations
==See also==

{{About|the natural and historical region|the present-day comarca of Aragon|Ribagorza/Ribagorça}} {{Infobox settlement | name =Ribagorça | other_name = Ribagorza / Rives Gorces | native_name_lang = <!-- ISO 639-2 code e.g. "fr" for French. If more than one, use {{lang}} instead --> | settlement_type = [[Natural region]] | image_skyline = Ribagorça isàbena 2.jpg | image_alt = | image_caption = Landscape of the region at the [[Isábena (river)|Isábena]] Valley. | image_flag = | flag_alt = | image_seal = | seal_alt = | image_shield = | shield_alt = | nickname = | motto = | image_map = | map_alt = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = Spain | pushpin_label_position = left | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|42.1875|N|0.334167|E|display=inline,title}} | coor_pinpoint = | coordinates_footnotes = | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = [[Spain]] | subdivision_type1 = | subdivision_name1 = | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name2 = | subdivision_type3 = | subdivision_name3 = <!-- ALL fields with measurements have automatic unit conversion --> <!-- for references: use <ref> tags --> | area_footnotes = | area_urban_footnotes = <!-- <ref> </ref> --> | area_rural_footnotes = <!-- <ref> </ref> --> | area_metro_footnotes = <!-- <ref> </ref> --> | area_magnitude = <!-- <ref> </ref> --> | area_note = | area_water_percent = | area_rank = | area_blank1_title = | area_blank2_title = <!-- square kilometers --> | area_total_km2 = | area_land_km2 = | area_water_km2 = | area_urban_km2 = | area_rural_km2 = | area_metro_km2 = | area_blank1_km2 = | area_blank2_km2 = <!-- hectares --> | area_total_ha = | area_land_ha = | area_water_ha = | area_urban_ha = | area_rural_ha = | area_metro_ha = | area_blank1_ha = | area_blank2_ha = | length_km = | width_km = | dimensions_footnotes = | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = 780 | population_footnotes = | population_total = | population_as_of = | population_density_km2 = auto | population_demonym = | population_note = | timezone1 = | utc_offset1 = | timezone1_DST = | utc_offset1_DST = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | footnotes = }} '''Ribagorça''' ({{IPA-ca|riβəˈɣoɾsə|lang}}) or '''Ribagorza''' ({{IPA-es|riβaˈɣoɾθa|lang}}; {{lang-fr|Rives Gorces}}) is a [[historical region|historical]] and [[natural region]] of [[Aragon]] and [[Franja de Ponent|historical Catalonia]]. Located in the [[Pre-Pyrenees]] and [[Pyrenees]] area, most of its territory is [[mountainous]]. The region has been steadily losing population since mid 20th century.<ref>[http://portal.aragob.es/servlet/page?_pageid=4097,591&_dad=portal30&_schema=PORTAL30&cuerpo.est=ITPG_EHE_IAEST_001COM002&menu.est=ITM_EHE_IAEST_inicio_menu Comarcal division, basic data (Aragonese Statistical Institute)]</ref>
The [[Noguera Ribagorçana]] river is named after this region.
==Geography== The region is located south of the French border with the [[Pallars]] in the east and the [[Sobrarbe]] in the west. The physiography of the Ribagorça natural region includes the [[Ésera]], [[Isábena (river)|Isábena]] and Noguera Ribagorçana river basins with their tributaries. The region also encompasses the mountain ranges spanning the Pyrenees and Pre-Pyrenees area that surrounds the basins of these south-flowing rivers.<ref>Manuel Serrano y Sanz, ''Noticias y documentos históricos del Condado de Ribagorza''</ref><ref>[http://www.enciclopedia.cat/EC-GEC-0006813.xml Josep Pla i Casadevall, ''Gran enciclopèdia catalana'' - la Baixa Ribagorça]</ref> {| |- valign="top" |[[File:Serra de Sis (Prepirineus).jpg|thumb|330px|The [[Mountains of Sis]], one of the mighty ranges of Ribagorça.]] |[[File:Benavarri.JPG|thumb|245px|View of [[Benabarre]] (Benavarri), the former capital of the region.]] |[[File:El Turbó..jpg|thumb|280px|[[El Turbón]]]] |}
===Municipalities=== The traditional capital of the region was [[Benabarre]] ({{lang-ca|Benavarri}}); according to the 2014 [[census]],<ref>[[Instituto Nacional de Estadística (Spain)|Instituto Nacional de Estadística (INE)]]</ref> the municipality has a population of 1,153 inhabitants. In present times, however, the most important town of the Ribagorça is [[Graus]] with a population of 3,429 in 2014.
===Present-day administrative divisions===
====Ribagorza/Ribagorça==== {{main|Ribagorza/Ribagorça}} Ribagorza/Ribagorça is a comarca of present-day Aragon established in 2002. It forms the northeastern part of [[Huesca (province)|Huesca Province]]. It borders the [[Departments of France|French ''département'']] of the [[Haute-Garonne]] to the north, the [[Aran Valley]], [[Alta Ribagorça]], [[Pallars Jussà]], and [[Noguera (comarca)|Noguera]] to the east, [[Sobrarbe]] to the west, as well as [[Somontano de Barbastro]] and [[La Litera|La Litera/La Llitera]] to the south.<ref>[http://portal.aragob.es/pls/portal30/docs/FOLDER/CA_EHE/FD_EHE_DOCUMENTACION/FD_EHE_DOCUMIAEST/FD_EHE_IAEST_001/FD_EHE_IAEST_001DB/FD_EHE_IAEST_001DB03/DB200312.PDF Comarcal statistics (Aragonese Statistical Institute)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The territory of the modern Aragonese comarca was traditionally known as ''Baixa Ribagorça'' in Catalan.<ref>A. Masiá de Ros, ''La cuestión de los límites enre Aragón y Cataluña''</ref>
====Alta Ribagorça==== {{main|Alta Ribagorça}} Present-day Alta Ribagorça is one of the [[Catalonia/Comarques|''comarques'' of Catalonia]]. Its capital is [[Pont de Suert]]. Other municipalities are [[Vall de Boí]] and [[Vilaller]].
==History== {{main|County of Ribagorça}} The [[County of Ribagorça]] was a historic [[county]] with its own dynasty between 872 and 1017. It became a county of the [[Kingdom of Aragon]] from 1018 to 1322, year in which it was joined to Aragon as an [[appanage]] or estate.<ref>Francesc Closa, Josep Manuel Martinez (eds.), ''Relaciones históricas entre Aragón y Cataluña. ... Autores Closa, Francesc (ed.)''.</ref> Ribagorça became part of the [[Spanish Crown]] in 1591 under [[Philip II of Spain|Philip II]].<ref>[https://www.academia.edu/3836082/La_organizaci%C3%B3n_del_territorio_y_las_din%C3%A1micas_sociales_en_Ribagorza_durante_la_gran_expansi%C3%B3n_medieval_1000-1300_ La organización del territorio y las dinámicas sociales en Ribagorza durante la gran expansión medieval (1000-1300)]</ref>
==Linguistics== [[Ribagorçan]] (''ribagorzano'', ''ribagorsano'') is a transitional [[Aragonese language|Aragonese]] and [[Catalan language|Catalan]] dialect spoken in the area of Aragon and [[Catalan Ribagorçan]] (''ribagorçà'') is a Catalan dialect spoken in the [[Alta Ribagorça]], Catalonia. Speakers of [[Pont de Suert]] use a Catalan variant transitional to Aragonese with some traits of [[Aranese dialect|Aranese]] [[Occitan language|Occitan]]. However, Aragonese and Catalan form a [[dialectal continuum]] in the region and it is not possible to draw the geographical limit of both languages in a clear-cut manner.<ref>[http://www.grec.cat/cgibin/heccl2.pgm?NDCHEC=0055285 Gran Enciclopèdia Catalana]</ref>
==See also== *[[Comarcas of Aragon]] *[[Comarques of Catalonia]] *[[Pallars]]
==References == {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *{{commonscat inline|Ribagorza}} * [http://www.benabarre.es/ Benabarre Municipality] *[http://www.ub.edu/geocrit/sn/sn-153.htm Jesús Burgueño, ''Reflexions i propostes al voltant del sisteme electoral a Catalunya: consells comarcals, diputacions, Parlament i representació a Corts'']

{{History of Chile}} The '''Royal Governor of Chile''' ruled over the Spanish colonial administrative district called the [[Captaincy General of Chile]], and as a result the Royal Governor also held the title of a '''[[Captaincy General|Captain General]]'''. There were 66 such governors or captains during the Spanish conquest and the later periods of Spanish-centered colonialism. == List of Governors == {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Rude Britain''''' (subtitled ''100 Rudest Place Names in Britain'') is a [[2005 in literature|2005 book]] of British place names with seemingly rude or offensive meanings.<ref>{{cite news |first= Sarah|last= Lyall|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=No Snickering: That Road Sign Means Something Else |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/23/world/europe/23crapstone.html |quote=Ed Hurst, a co-author, with Rob Bailey, of “Rude Britain” and “Rude UK,” which list arguably offensive place names — some so arguably offensive that, unfortunately, they cannot be printed here — said that many such communities were established hundreds of years ago and that their names were not rude at the time. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=2009-01-23 }}</ref> The book ({{ISBN|0-7522-2581-2}}) is written by Rob Bailey and Ed Hurst, and published in the United Kingdom by the [[Macmillan Publishers|Pan Macmillan]] [[imprint (trade name)|imprint]] Boxtree.
Each of the 100 names chosen by the authors is accompanied by a photograph and a placename [[etymology]]. The etymologies are often due to Great Britain's history of repeated invasion, occupation, and assimilation, combined with a human [[wikt:predilection|predilection]] for ''[[double entendre]]s''.
[[Image:Twatt road sign.jpg|thumb|right|Road sign pointing to [[Twatt, Shetland]]]]
Entries include North Piddle (from the [[Old English language|Old English]] word ''pidele'', meaning [[marsh]]), [[Pratt's Bottom]], [[Ugley]], Titty Ho, and [[Spital-in-the-Street]] (a [[Hamlet (place)|hamlet]] in [[Lincolnshire]] with a name based on the [[Middle English]] ''spitel'', meaning hospital).
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110715043742/http://www.panmacmillan.com/titles/displayPage.asp?PageTitle=Individual%20Title&BookID=376016 Publisher's summary of the book]
[[Category:2005 books]] [[Category:British toponymy]] [[Category:British humour]] [[Category:Lists of United Kingdom placename etymology]] [[Category:Travel guide books]] [[Category:Slang]] [[Category:British books]]

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} A '''sea lane''', '''sea road''' or '''shipping lane''' is a regularly used route for [[Ship|vessels]] on oceans and large lakes. In the [[Age of Sail]] they were not only determined by the distribution of land masses but also the [[prevailing wind]]s, whose discovery was crucial for the success of long voyages. Sea lanes are very important for [[trade]] by sea.
==History== [[Image:Map prevailing winds on earth.png|thumb|The westerlies and trade winds]] [[Image:Corrientes-oceanicas.png|thumb|The ocean currents]]
{{Main|Wind#Global_climatology}} The establishment of the [[North Atlantic Ocean|North Atlantic]] sea lanes was inspired by the sinking of the US [[mail]] [[Steamboat|steamer]] [[SS Arctic]] by [[collision]] with the French steamer ''SS Vesta'' in October 1854 which resulted in the loss of over 300 lives. Lieutenant M. F. Maury of the US Navy first published a section titled "Steam Lanes Across the Atlantic" in his 1855 ''Sailing Directions'' proposing sea lanes along the 42 degree [[latitude]]. A number of international conferences and committees were held in 1866, 1872, 1887, 1889, and 1891 all of which left the designation of sea lanes to the principal trans-Atlantic steamship companies at the time; [[Cunard Line|Cunard]], [[White Star Line|White Star]], [[Inman Line|Inman]], [[National Line]], and [[Guion Line]]s. In 1913–1914 the [[International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea|International Convention for Safety of Life at Sea]] held in [[London]] again reaffirmed that the selection of routes across the Atlantic in both directions is left to the responsibility of the steamship companies.<ref>Encyclopædia Britannica, Fourteenth Edition, Volume 20 pp. 539, 1938</ref>
Shipping lanes came to be by analysing the prevailing winds. The trade winds allowed ships to sail towards the west quickly, and that the westerlies allowed ships to travel to the east quickly. As such, the sea lanes are mostly chosen to take full advantage of these winds. Currents are also similarly followed as well, which also gives an advantage to the vessel. {{Citation needed|date=August 2010}}
Some routes, such as that from [[Cape Town]] to [[Rio de Janeiro]] (passing [[Tristan da Cunha]]), weren't able to take advantage of these natural factors.
Main sea lanes may also attract [[pirate]]s.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} ''[[Pax Britannica]]'' was the period from 1815–1914 during which the British [[Royal Navy]] controlled most of the key maritime trade routes, and also suppressed piracy and the slave trade.
During [[World War I]], as German [[U-boat]]s began hitting [[United States|American]] and [[United Kingdom|British]] [[shipping]], the [[Allies of World War I|Allied]] trade vessels began to move out of the usual sea lanes to be escorted by [[naval ship]]s.
==Advantages== [[Image:Cardinal mark (east) in ice in front of South Harbor Helsinki Finland.jpg|thumb|Behind the cardinal mark is a sea lane opened on an ice-covered sea.]]
Although most ships no longer use sails (having switched them for engines), the wind still creates waves, and this can cause [[heeling (sailing)|heeling]]. As such following the overall direction of the trade winds and westerlies is still very useful. However, any vessel that is not engaged in trading, or is smaller than a certain length, is best to avoid the lanes. This is not only because the slight chance of a collision with a large ship can easily cause a smaller ship to sink, but also because large vessels are much less maneuverable than smaller ships, and need much more depth. Smaller ships can thus easily take courses that are nearer to the shore. Unlike with road traffic, there is no exact "road" a ship must follow, so this can easily be done.
Shipping lanes are the busiest parts of the sea, thus being a useful place for stranded boaters whose boats are sinking or people on a liferaft to boat to, and be rescued by a passing ship.
==Threats from shipping lanes== {{multiple image| align = right | footer = '''Left''': This map of shipping routes illustrates the present-day density of commercial shipping in the world's oceans. '''Right''': 16th century and current day trade routes prey to pirating and privateering.| footer_align = left | image1 =Shipping routes red black.png | caption1 = | image2 =16th century Portuguese Spanish trade routes.png | caption2 = }}
Although the shipping lanes are useful, they do pose threats to some people: * Divers should stay clear of shipping lanes when performing dives. * Small boats also do best to avoid the lanes, in risk of conflicts with bigger ships. * As the shipping lanes are very large, sections of the lane exist which can be shallow or have some kind of obstruction (e.g. [[sand bank]]). This threat is greatest when passing some narrows, such as between islands in the Indian Ocean (e.g. in Indonesia) as well as between islands in the Pacific (e.g. near the Marquesas islands, Tahiti) * Some shipping lanes, such as the [[Straits of Malacca]] off [[Indonesia]] and [[Malaysia]], and the waters off [[Somalia]], are frequented by [[Piracy|pirates]] operating independently or as [[privateers]] (for companies and countries). Passing ships run the risk of being attacked and held for ransom.
==See also== * [[Age of sail]] * [[Sea lines of communication]] * [[Roadstead]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sea Lane}} [[Category:Navigation|Lane]] [[Category:International water transport|Lane]] [[Category:Trade routes]]

{{Italic title}} [[File:Speculum Orbis Terrae.jpg|thumb|upright=0.85|right|Title page of ''Speculum Orbis Terrae''.]] '''''Speculum Orbis Terrae''''' ("Mirror of the World") was an atlas published by [[Cornelis de Jode]] in Antwerp in 1593. The atlas was largely a continuation of unfinished works of his father, [[Gerard de Jode]], who died in 1591. Contemporary scholars consider many of de Jode's maps to be superior, both in detail and style, to those of the competing atlas of the time, ''[[Theatrum Orbis Terrarum]]'', by [[Ortelius]]. However, de Jode's atlas never sold well.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sanderusmaps.com/antique-maps/world-and-polar-regions/world-_20635.cfm|title= Antique map of World by de Jode|accessdate=2009-03-09 |work= |publisher= |date= }}</ref>
After de Jode's death in 1600, the engraving plates were sold to J. B. Vrients (who also owned the Ortelius plates), and the complete work was not published again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maphist.com/artman/publish/article_69.shtml|title=MapHist, DE JODE, Cornelis|accessdate=2009-03-09|work=|publisher=|date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106190731/http://www.maphist.com/artman/publish/article_69.shtml|archivedate=2009-01-06|df=}}</ref>
{{Clear}}
==Gallery== {| | [[File:Gerard de Jode 1593 Map Northern hemisphere.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Map of the Northern hemisphere. Color print from copper engraving (printer Arnold Coninx), Antwerp, 1593.]] | [[File:Gerard de Jode 1593 Map Southern hemisphere.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Map of the Southern hemisphere.]] |} [[File:Cornelis de Jode 1593 Totius Orbis Cogniti Universalis Descriptio.jpg|thumb|The known world from Speculum Orbis Terrae, 1593.]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Atlases]] [[Category:1593 books]] [[Category:Cartography in the Dutch Republic]]

{{Infobox country telephone plan | country = Kazakhstan | country_link = Kazakhstan | continent = Asia | map_image = Kazakhstan (orthographic projection).svg | map_caption = Location of Kazakhstan | map_size = 200px | map_alt = | country_calling_code = +7 | international_prefix = 008, 009, 010 | trunk_prefix = 008 | regulator = Ministry of Transport and Communications of the Republic of Kazakhstan | plan_membership = | nsn_length = 10 | dial_plan_type = [[Open telephone numbering plan|Open]] | number_format = (xxx) xxx xx xx
(xxxx) xx xx xx
(xxxxx) x xx xx | codes_list = Area codes in Kazakhstan }} '''Telephone numbers in Kazakhstan''' are under a unified numbering plan with [[Russia]] with the [[List of country calling codes|country calling code]] +7. Historically, +7 was used as the [[Soviet Union]] country calling code. Following the break-up of the Soviet Union, all former republics except [[Russia]] and [[Kazakhstan]] switched to new country codes. As in Russia, Kazakhstan employs a four-level (local, zone, country, international) open dialing plan. A national number consists of ten digits: *zone code consists of the leading three digits *area code consists of the following one or two digits *subscribers number consists of the last six or five digits, depending on the length of the area code. The international dialing prefix is "8~10" - callers dial '8', wait for a tone, and then dial '10', followed by the country code, area code and number. The long distance dialing prefix is "8" - callers dial '8', wait for a tone, and then dial the area code and number. Under an agreement with Russia on 11 June 2006, Kazakhstan is assigned zone codes 6xx and 7xx (x = 0 to 9) under the unified plan. Land lines are in geographic zone codes from 710 to 729, mobiles are in zone codes 70x and 77x, and other services are in 75x and 76x.{{cite web|last=Agency of the Republic of Kazakhstan for Informatization and Communication|title=Communication of 7.II.2012|url=http://www.itu.int/dms_pub/itu-t/oth/02/02/T020200006F0001MSWE.docx|publisher=ITU|accessdate=11 April 2012}} Previously, land lines used zone codes in the 3xx range. As zone codes 3xx are assigned to Russia, zone codes 3xx in Kazakhstan were changed by substituting the leading '3' with '7'. == References == {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[Telephone numbers in Russia]] {{Telephone numbers in Europe}} {{Telephone numbers in Asia}} [[Category:Telephone numbers by country|Kazakhstan]] [[Category:Communications in Kazakhstan]] [[Category:Kazakhstan communications-related lists]] {{Kazakhstan-stub}} {{Telephonenumber-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=August 2014}} '''Tri-state area''' is an informal term in the eastern [[contiguous United States]] for any of several regions associated with a particular town or metropolis that, with adjacent suburbs, lies across three [[U.S. state|state]]s. Some of these involve a state boundary [[tripoint]]. Other tri-state areas have a more diffuse population that shares a connected economy and geography—especially with respect to geology, botany, or climate—such as the tri-state area of [[New York (state)|New York]], [[New Jersey]], and [[Connecticut]]. The term "tri-state area" often occurs in [[Film|movies]] and [[radio]] and [[television]] commercials.
==Tri-state areas==
* The [[Pittsburgh metropolitan area|Pittsburgh]] tri-state area, covering parts of [[Pennsylvania]], [[Ohio]], and [[West Virginia]].
* The [[New York metropolitan area]], which covers parts of the states of [[New York (state)|New York]], [[New Jersey]], and [[Connecticut]].
* The [[Delaware Valley]] region, which includes eastern Pennsylvania, southern New Jersey, and northern [[Delaware]].
* The [[Cincinnati metropolitan area|Cincinnati]], including [[Ohio]], [[Kentucky]], and [[Indiana]].
* The Chicago tri-state area, also known as [[Chicago metropolitan area|Chicagoland]], which includes parts of [[Illinois]], [[Indiana]], and [[Wisconsin]].
* The [[Memphis metropolitan area|Greater Memphis]] area or [[Mid-South (region)|Mid-South]] consisting of [[West Tennessee]], North [[Mississippi]], and the [[Arkansas]] delta.
* The [[Dubuque area|Dubuque, Iowa tri-state area]] spills over into [[Illinois]] and [[Wisconsin]].
* The [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]] tri-state area includes portions of [[Alabama]] and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].
*The North Eastern most part of Maryland that runs into Delaware and Pennsylvania.
* The [[Washington metropolitan area|area that includes Washington, D.C., and the nearby parts of Maryland and the Virginia]] is sometimes loosely referred to as a "tri-state area," although the District of Columbia is not a state; however, with the presence of [[Jefferson County, West Virginia]], in the official Washington–Arlington–Alexandria [[metropolitan statistical area]], the region, as defined by the US Government, ''does'' in fact include three states. This area is colloquially referred to as "the DMV" (DC, Maryland, Virginia).
* The "[[Tri-State district|Joplin District]]", a [[lead]] and [[zinc]] [[mining]] region of Oklahoma, Kansas, and Missouri, produces mineral specimens known as "tri-state" minerals, typically consisting mainly of [[sphalerite]].
* The [[Quincy, Illinois]] tri-state area includes parts of [[Missouri]] and [[Iowa]].
* The [[Illinois–Indiana–Kentucky tri-state area]] includes [[Evansville, Indiana]], and adjacent parts of Illinois and Kentucky.
* The [[Huntington-Ashland metropolitan area]] incorporates towns in ten counties in [[Kentucky]], [[Ohio]], and [[West Virginia]]. This area is sometimes referred to as “Kyova”, a portmanteau of the state abbreviations.
* The [[Wiregrass Region]] includes [[Southeast Alabama]], Southern [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and the [[Florida Panhandle]].
The Quincy, Evansville, and Huntington–Ashland areas are noteworthy for the states included all being separated by rivers.
==Tripoints==
===Land=== Of the 62 points in the United States where three and only three states meet (each of which may be associated with its own tri-state area), 34 are on dry land and 28 are in water.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/parsell.pdf |title=Tri State Corners in the United States|publisher=Jack Parsell}}</ref>
[[File:NY-MA-CT Tripoint Marker.jpg|thumb|right|275px|NY–MA–CT tripoint marker]] [[Image:CT-RI-MA Tripoint.JPG|thumb|right|275px|CT–RI–MA tripoint marker]] [[File:NJ-NY-PA Tripoint Marker - 2014-10-08 - image 1.JPG|thumb|right|275px|NJ–NY–PA tripoint marker]] [[File:Indiana-Michigan-Ohio Tri-Point Marker.jpg|thumb|right|275px|IN–MI–OH tripoint marker]] [[File:8 Mile Corner marker.jpg|thumb|right|275px|CO–KS–OK tripoint marker ([[8 Mile Corner]])]]
{| class="wikitable sortable" width="70%" |- !width="15%"|State 1 !width="15%"|State 2 !width="15%"|State 3 !width="55%"|Notes |- | [[Alabama]] | [[Florida]] | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | Marker on riverbank is actually a few feet above and west of true tripoint at high-water line. |- | [[Alabama]] | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | [[Tennessee]] | Marker on dry land at surface level and unmarked on lake in cavern directly below. Stolen in 2009 and returned two years later.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wheatley|first1=Thomas|title=Camak Stone, border marker between Tennessee and Georgia, is missing|url=http://www.creativeloafing.com/news/article/13048687/camak-stone-border-marker-between-tennessee-and-georgia-is-missing|website=Creativeloafing.com|accessdate=7 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Vardeman|first1=Johnny|title=Stolen stone returns home minus fanfare|url=http://www.gainesvilletimes.com/archives/48279/|accessdate=7 May 2017|newspaper=[[The Gainesville Times (Georgia)|Gainesville Times]]}}</ref> |- | [[Arizona]] | [[Nevada]] | [[Utah]] | Marked with a red sandstone monument.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/pointdetail.php3?point=12|title=Arizona - Nevada - Utah Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Arkansas]] | [[Louisiana]] | [[Mississippi]] | Unmarked on silt island in river connected to west bank by riprap. |- | [[Arkansas]] | [[Louisiana]] | [[Texas]] | See [[Ark-La-Tex]]. Marker in process of being surrounded and absorbed by tree. |- | [[Arkansas]] | [[Missouri]] | [[Oklahoma]] | Marked with a stone monument.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/pointdetail.php3?point=6|title=Arkansas - Missouri - Oklahoma Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Arkansas]] | [[Oklahoma]] | [[Texas]] | Unmarked on seasonal silt island or in river bed, but Oklahoma-Texas state line as revised in 2000 is defective in not extending from vegetation line on south bank to pre-established tripoint. |- | [[California]] | [[Nevada]] | [[Oregon]] | Marked with a [[cairn]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/canvor.pdf|format=PDF|title=Oregon - California - Nevada Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Colorado]] | [[Kansas]] | [[Nebraska]] | Marked with a brass disc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/coksne.pdf|format=PDF|title=Colorado - Nebraska - Kansas Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Colorado]] | [[Kansas]] | [[Oklahoma]] | [[8 Mile Corner]]. Marker is concealed in crypt beneath removable manhole cover. |- | [[Colorado]] | [[Nebraska]] | [[Wyoming]] | Marked with a stone surrounded by a three-stone colored base.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/conewy.pdf|format=PDF|title=Colorado - Nebraska - Wyoming Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Colorado]] | [[New Mexico]] | [[Oklahoma]] | [[Preston Monument]] |- | [[Colorado]] | [[Utah]] | [[Wyoming]] | Marked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/coutwy.pdf|format=PDF|title=Colorado - Utah - Wyoming Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Connecticut]] | [[Massachusetts]] | [[New York (state)|New York]] | See [[Brace Mountain]] or [[Mount Frissell]]. Marked with a stone inscribed with MASS-1898-NY and sometimes a "scratched-on" CONN.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/pointdetail.php3?point=19|title=Connecticut - Massachusetts - New York Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Connecticut]] | [[Massachusetts]] | [[Rhode Island]] | See [[Thompson, Connecticut]]. Marked with a stone inscribed with MASS-CONN-RI.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/pointdetail.php3?point=20|title=Connecticut - Massachusetts - Rhode Island Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Delaware]] | [[Maryland]] | [[Pennsylvania]] | See [[Wedge (border)|Delaware Wedge]]. Marked with a stone inscribed with M-M-P-P, as this was not the original intended tri-point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/pointdetail.php3?point=24|title=Delaware - Maryland - Pennsylvania Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | [[North Carolina]] | [[Tennessee]] | Marked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/ganctn.pdf|format=PDF|title=Georgia - North Carolina - Tennessee Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Idaho]] | [[Montana]] | [[Wyoming]] | Located within [[Yellowstone National Park]]. Marked, although difficult to access.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/idmtwy.pdf|format=PDF|title=Idaho - Montana - Wyoming Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Idaho]] | [[Nevada]] | [[Oregon]] | Marked with a three-sided stone inscribed with N-I-O on the respective faces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/idnvor.pdf|format=PDF|title=Idaho - Nevada - Oregon Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Idaho]] | [[Nevada]] | [[Utah]] | Marked with a granite monument inscribed with the respective states' names.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/idnvut.pdf|format=PDF|title=Idaho - Nevada - Utah Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Idaho]] | [[Utah]] | [[Wyoming]] | Marked with a stone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/idutwy.pdf|format=PDF|title=Idaho - Utah - Wyoming Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Indiana]] | [[Michigan]] | [[Ohio]] | Brass marker with the shapes of the three states is located in a monument box beneath the surface of a rural road. Was set in 1999<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/inmioh.pdf|format=PDF|title=Jack Parsell's description of the IN-MI-OH tripoint|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> and is referenced by a granite marker 20 feet to the east on the Michigan-Ohio line.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geocaching.com/seek/cache_details.aspx?wp=GC2018&title=tristate-marker|title=Geocaching - The Official Global GPS Cache Hunt Site|website=Geocaching.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Iowa]] | [[Minnesota]] | [[South Dakota]] | True point is marked with a disc in the center of a T-shaped road intersection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/photos/IAMNSDBrian.jpg|format=JPG|title=Photo by Gregg A. Butler of the IA-MN-SD tripoint and its witness post|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> A witness monument nearby in the South Dakota corner acknowledges the tri-point being set in 1859. |- | [[Kansas]] | [[Missouri]] | [[Oklahoma]] | Marked with a plaque on a seldom used dead-end road.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/pointdetail.php3?point=46|title=Kansas - Missouri - Oklahoma Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Kentucky]] | [[Tennessee]] | [[Virginia]] | [[Tri-State Peak]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/archive/cuga/tristate.htm|title=KY-TN-VA Tri-State Peak at Cumberland Gap National Historical Park|author=|date=|website=Nps.gov|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> Located within [[Cumberland Gap National Historical Park]]. Marked. |- | [[Kentucky]] | [[Virginia]] | [[West Virginia]] | Marked with a USGS marker on top of a two-foot high iron pipe at the river's high point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/kyvawv.pdf|format=PDF|title=Kentucky - Virginia - West Virginia Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Maryland]] | [[Pennsylvania]] | [[West Virginia]] | Marked with a pyramid-like stone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/mdpawv.pdf|format=PDF|title=Maryland - Pennsylvania - West Virginia Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Massachusetts]] | [[New Hampshire]] | [[Vermont]] | Marker is technically on dry land, but buried within river bed due to a dam's construction downstream.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Td6CNJ_Z1ZMC&pg=PA114&lpg=PA114&dq=%22mud+turtle%22+hampshire+vermont+massachusetts&source=web&ots=_R7HTcswER&sig=vxfZQtiKqtWCezxNLxMgwvnQCHQ&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result Eric Jones. ''New Hampshire Curiosities''. Globe Pequot, 2006. p. 114-5]</ref> |- | [[Massachusetts]] | [[New York (state)|New York]] | [[Vermont]] | Marked with a stone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/pointdetail.php3?point=54|title=Massachusetts - New York - Vermont Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Montana]] | [[North Dakota]] | [[South Dakota]] | Marked with a red granite stone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/mtndsd.pdf|format=PDF|title=Montana - North Dakota - South Dakota Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Montana]] | [[South Dakota]] | [[Wyoming]] | Marked with a stone within a fence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/mtsdwy.pdf|format=PDF|title=Montana - South Dakota - Wyoming Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Nebraska]] | [[South Dakota]] | [[Wyoming]] | Marked with a stone within a fence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/nesdwy.pdf|format=PDF|title=Nebraska - South Dakota - Wyoming Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[New Mexico]] | [[Oklahoma]] | [[Texas]] | [[Texhomex|Texomex Marker]] |- | [[North Carolina]] | [[Tennessee]] | [[Virginia]] | Marked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/docs/nctnva.pdf|format=PDF|title=North Carolina - Tennessee - Virginia Tristate|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |}

It is the [[New London, Connecticut]] metro area. |- | [[Delaware]] | [[New Jersey]] | [[Pennsylvania]] | [[Delaware River]] | [[Philadelphia]] [[Delaware Valley|metro area]], at the east end of the [[Twelve-Mile Circle]]. |- | [[Florida]] | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | [[Alabama]] | [[Chattahoochee River]] | Located in river very near marker on dry land. |- | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | [[North Carolina]] | [[South Carolina]] | [[Chatooga River]] | Located in river very near marker on dry land. |- | [[Idaho]] | [[Oregon]] | [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] | [[Snake River]] | |- | [[Illinois]] | [[Indiana]] | [[Kentucky]] | [[Wabash River]] and [[Ohio River]] | [[Evansville, Indiana]] metro area. See [[Illinois–Indiana–Kentucky tri-state area]]. |- | [[Illinois]] | [[Indiana]] | [[Michigan]] | [[Lake Michigan]] | Known as either the Indiana Dunes or the Michigan Dunes Area |- | [[Illinois]] | [[Iowa]] | [[Wisconsin]] | [[Mississippi River]] | [[Dubuque, Iowa]] metro area. |- | [[Illinois]] | [[Kentucky]] | [[Missouri]] | [[Mississippi River]] and [[Ohio River]] | [[Southern Illinois|Little Egypt]] region popularly labeled as a tri-state area with [[St. Louis, Missouri]], [[Carbondale, Illinois]] metro area, and [[Paducah, Kentucky]] being its nuclei. |- | [[Illinois]] | [[Michigan]] | [[Wisconsin]] | [[Lake Michigan]] | |- | [[Indiana]] | [[Kentucky]] | [[Ohio]] | [[Ohio River]] | [[Cincinnati – Northern Kentucky metropolitan area|Cincinnati, Ohio metro area]]. The tripoint is near, but not precisely at, the confluence with the [[Great Miami River]]. |- | [[Iowa]] | [[Illinois]] | [[Missouri]] | [[Mississippi River]] and [[Des Moines River]] | Border with [[Lee County, Iowa]] |- | [[Iowa]] | [[Minnesota]] | [[Wisconsin]] | [[Mississippi River]] | [[La Crosse, Wisconsin]] metro area. Was apparently marked at one time with a sign that had been anchored in the location, but that sign has since been moved as of 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjbsoftware.com/corners/pointdetail.php3?point=31|title=Iowa - Minnesota - Wisconsin Tri-state|website=Bjbsoftware.com|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Iowa]] | [[Missouri]] | [[Nebraska]] | [[Missouri River]] | |- | [[Iowa]] | [[Nebraska]] | [[South Dakota]] | [[Big Sioux River]] and [[Missouri River]] | [[Sioux City]], Iowa metro area. |- | [[Kansas]] | [[Missouri]] | [[Nebraska]] | [[Missouri River]] | |- | [[Kentucky]] | [[Missouri]] | [[Tennessee]] | [[Mississippi River]] | Three separate tripoints, due to meanders of the river (though probably only a single tri-state area surrounding them all). See also [[Kentucky Bend]]. |- | [[Kentucky]] | [[Ohio]] | [[West Virginia]] | [[Big Sandy River (Ohio River)|Big Sandy River]] and [[Ohio River]] | [[Huntington–Ashland, WV–KY–OH, Metropolitan Statistical Area|Huntington (W.V.)-Ashland (Ky.)-Ironton (Oh.) Tri-State region]]. |- | [[Maryland]] | [[Virginia]] | [[West Virginia]] | [[Potomac River]] | Unmarked, at low water line, and almost always submerged. |- | [[Michigan]] | [[Minnesota]] | [[Wisconsin]] | [[Lake Superior]] | |- | [[Minnesota]] | [[North Dakota]] | [[South Dakota]] | [[Bois de Sioux River]] | Not directly marked and most probably within river. |- | [[New Jersey]] | [[New York (state)|New York]] | [[Pennsylvania]] | [[Middle of Delaware River]] | Mistakenly marked by so-called Tri-States Monument on left bank of river. |- | [[Ohio]] | [[Pennsylvania]] | [[West Virginia]] | [[Ohio River]] | Technically the [[Beginning Point of the U.S. Public Land Survey]], although the actual monument is 1,112 feet north of the tripoint due to the tripoint's current location under water; [[Pittsburgh Tri-State]]. |}
==Regions with no tripoint==
The following tri-state areas are also notable, but have no tripoint:
